title: Introduction to ROS2
text: Robotic Operating System 2 (ROS2) is a powerful framework for building robotic systems that has gained popularity in recent years. In addition to its robust capabilities for building and simulating robots, ROS2 also includes several security features that make it ideal for use in industrial applications.

title: Introduction to ROS2
text:
Secure Communication
ROS2 uses DDS protocol to provide a secure communication channel between nodes in the system. DDS includes built-in support for secure communication using Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Datagram Transport Layer Security (DTLS) protocols, which help to protect against eavesdropping, tampering, and replay attacks.

title: Introduction to ROS2
text:
Access Control
ROS2 includes a new access control system that allows system administrators to control access to different parts of the system. This includes the ability to define roles and permissions to different users and groups, and to restrict access to sensitive data and resources.

title: Introduction to ROS2
text:
Encryption
ROS2 supports end-to-end encryption for communication between nodes. This means that data is encrypted at the source and decrypted only at the destination, providing an additional layer of security against unauthorized access.

title: Introduction to ROS2
text:
Authentication
ROS2 includes built-in support for authentication, which helps to prevent unauthorized access to the system. Authentication can be based on variety of factors, including user credentials, digital certificates, and biometric data.

title: Introduction to ROS2
text:
Improved Logging
ROS2 includes a new logging system that provides better support for logging security-related events. This makes it easier for administrators to monitor the system for potential security threats and take appropriate action if necessary.

title: A second .bash_history
text: As a system administrator, you may need to keep track of all commands typed on your Linux system, even if multiple terminal windows are used or commands are typed with a leading space or tab. In this blog post, you will be shown how to configure the syslog facility to capture all commands typed on your system and save them to a log file.

title: A second .bash_history
text:
Step 1: Configure the Syslog Facility
The syslog facility is a powerful logging system that can be used to capture and store system messages, including all commands typed on the system. To configure syslog to capture command history, you need to edit the /etc/rsyslog.conf file and add the following lines at the end of the file:
$InputFilePollInterval 1
$InputFileName /var/log/command_history.log
$InputFileStateFile stat-command_history
$InputFileTag command_history:
$InputFileFacility local6
$InputRunFileMonitor
These lines instruct rsyslog to monitor the command_history.log file for new entries and tag them with the command_history tag. You can replace command_history.log with any filename you prefer.

title: A second .bash_history
section: Step 2: Create the Log File and Set Permissions
text:
Step 2: Create the Log File and Set Permissions
Next, you need to create the log file and set the appropriate permissions. To create the log file, run the following commands:
sudo touch /var/log/command_history.log
sudo chown syslog:adm /var/log/command_history.log
sudo chmod 640 /var/log/command_history.log
These commands create the log file, set the owner to syslog and the group to adm, and give read and write permissions to the owner and group only.

title: A second .bash_history
text:
Step 3: Restart the Rsyslog Service
Finally, you need to restart the rsyslog service to apply the changes. To do this, run the following command:
sudo service rsyslog restart
Now, whenever a user types a command in any terminal window on the system, the command will be captured by syslog and written to the command_history.log file, along with other details such as the time and date, the user who typed the command, and the terminal window in which the command was typed.

title: A second .bash_history
text:
Conclusion
In this blog post, we showed you how to configure syslog to capture the history of all commands typed on your Linux system, even if using multiple terminals and starting with space. This method can be useful for system administrators who need to keep track of user activity on their systems. However, keep in mind that capturing command history in this way may raise privacy concerns, so it’s important to inform your users that their commands are being monitored and ensure that the log file is kept secure and accessible only to authorized personnel.

Why is Time Management Important?

“Time is a created thing. To say ‘I don’t have time,’ is like saying, ‘I don’t want to.’” - Lao Tzu

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

“The trouble with time management is that nobody tells you how to manage time. They tell you to buy a planner, and then they assume you will use it.” - Dr. Mardy Grothe

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh

Time Management and Work-Life Balance

“The bad news is time flies. The good news is you’re the pilot.” - Michael Altshuler

Definition of inventory

What ?  I think this is inventory 


Yes. You are right.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

Cost Control
Customer Satisfaction
Efficient Operations
Accurate financial reporting
Planning and forecasting

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

Ensuring Adequate supply
Reducing costs
Improving efficiency
Maximizing profitability
Providing data for decision-making

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
The primary functions of inventory

Supporting production
Meeting customer demand
Reducing lead timers
Providing a safety net
Facilitating economies of scale

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
Importance of balancing inventory functions

Inventory balancing is the process of moving excess inventory from one retail location to a retail location where that inventory is in demand.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

Holding costs
Ordering costs
Shortage costs
Obsolescence costs
Quality costs

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

Demand variability
Lead time variability
Order Quality
Seasonality
Supply chain distruptions
Product perishablility

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:

Raw Materials

Consignment Inventory
Safety Stocks
Obsolete Inventory
Perishable Inventory
Seasonal Inventory

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
section: What is a deterministic inventory model?
text:
What is a deterministic inventory model?

A deterministic inventory model is a type of inventory management system that assumes that demand for a product is known and constant.

Examples:



Economic Order Quantity (EOQ) 



Reorder Point (ROP)

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
section: What is a probabilistic inventory model?
text:
What is a probabilistic inventory model?

Probabilistic inventory models are mathematical models used in inventory management that take into account uncertain demand and other random variables that can affect inventory levels.

Examples:

Periodic Review Model
Continuous Review Model

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
Pros and Cons
Deterministic Inventory Models







Advantages
Disadvantages




Simple and easy to understand.
Assumes a constant demand, which may not reflect actual demand variability.


Suitable for situations where demand and lead times are known and constant.
Doesn’t account for uncertainty and risk.


Provides a precise calculation of inventory levels.
May lead to stockouts or overstocking if demand or lead times vary.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
Pros and Cons
Probabilistic Inventory Models







Advantages
Disadvantages




Can account for demand and lead time variability.
More complex than deterministic models.


Provides more realistic estimates of inventory levels.
Requires accurate data and statistical analysis.


Can incorporate uncertainty and risk into decision-making.
May involve assumptions that may not hold true in practice.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
What is a quantity discount?

Quantity discount is a pricing strategy used by businesses to encourage customers to purchase more of a product by offering discounts for larger quantities.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
section: How quantity discounts affect inventory costs
text:
How quantity discounts affect inventory costs

Ordering a larger quantity of a product to get a quantity discount can be a smart move for a business.
However, storing excess inventory can lead to additional costs such as rent, utilities, and insurance for a warehouse or storage facility.
Holding excess inventory can tie up capital that could be used for other purposes, increasing the opportunity cost of inventory.
Excess inventory can become obsolete or spoil over time, leading to additional costs associated with disposal or write-offs.
These costs can offset the savings gained from the quantity discount, so it’s important to carefully consider the trade-offs before ordering in bulk.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
section: What is a perpetual inventory control system?
text:
What is a perpetual inventory control system?

A perpetual inventory control system is a method of inventory management that maintains a continuous record of inventory levels and transactions in real-time.




It uses technology such as barcode scanners and inventory management software to track the movement of goods.
Inventory levels are updated automatically with each transaction, allowing businesses to have a real-time view of their inventory levels.
Benefits include increased accuracy, reduced inventory holding costs, improved efficiency in managing inventory, and better visibility into stock levels.
Implementing and maintaining the system can be costly and requires ongoing training and support for employees.

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
section: What is a periodic inventory control system?
text:
What is a periodic inventory control system?

A periodic inventory control system involves physical inventory counts at regular intervals, such as monthly or annually.


The system relies on manual counts and does not provide real-time updates of inventory levels.
Inventory levels are updated periodically to reflect the purchases, sales, and other inventory movements that occurred during the period.
This system can be less accurate than a perpetual inventory control system, as it is more susceptible to errors and discrepancies.
The periodic inventory control system is often used by small businesses or those with a low volume of inventory, as it requires less investment in technology and resources.

text: Category: Gallery

title: Rishikesavan Ramesh
text:
I am a Mechatronics student with a passion for both robotics and cybersecurity. Currently, I am focusing on expanding my cybersecurity skills while also learning ROS2 to develop secure and efficient robotics systems.
As I delve deeper into cybersecurity, I am gaining knowledge in areas such as network security, cryptography, and risk management. I am also learning how to design secure and reliable systems that can protect against threats and vulnerabilities.
At the same time, my interest in robotics has led me to explore ROS2, which allows me to create complex robotics systems that can operate in diverse environments. I am fascinated by ROS2’s capabilities and the potential to develop secure and efficient systems.
Furthermore, my experience in mechatronics has provided me with a strong foundation in PLCs, hydraulics, and pneumatics, which I am excited to apply to create innovative and secure systems.
Overall, I am excited about combining my skills in mechatronics, cybersecurity, and ROS2 to create innovative and secure robotics systems that can make a positive impact on society.@
